GPIF - GPIF confirmed to raise allocation limits of investments in foreign bonds to 25% from 15% with a permissible range of deviation of 6% and cut domestic bond allocations to 25% from 35%, while allocation of foreign and domestic stocks are maintained at 25% each. (Newswires)

Other News - Japanese PM Abe reiterated to deploy powerful measure to address the economic damage from coronavirus, while ruling LDP party official Kishida announced proposal for JPY 60tln economic stimulus plan. (Newswires)

BoJ BoJ announced the establishment of amount of cash collateral rule for lending of ETS effective today. (Newswires)

BoJ April Purchase Plans include: 

  • JPY 200-450bln of 1-3yr JGBs six times in April (March bought JPY 300-500bln four times)

DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
CORONAVIRUS UPDATE / RESPONSES

US President Trump tweeted that this is the time for our long awaited infrastructure bill as US interest rates are at 0%, while he added it should be big and bold at USD 2tln, focusing solely on jobs and rebuilding infrastructure, which he suggested is 'Phase 4'. (Twitter)

NIH’s Fauci said we are starting to see some glimmers that social distancing measures are working within the US and are beginning to see people in their 30's and 40's becoming seriously ill, while he added cases are still rising and situation remains dangerous. (Newswires)

Texas Governor issued a Stay at Home order in which all Texans are to stay at home except for exceptional business. (Newswires)

Italy COVID-19 cases rose to 105,792 (prev. 101,739) and death toll increased by 837 to 12,428. There were also comments from Italy's National Health Institute head that the number of virus deaths could be understated. (Newswires)

UK COVID-19 number of cases rose to 25,150 (prev. 22,141) and the death toll rose to 1,801 (prev. 1,408). There were also comments by UK Cabinet Minister Gove that there may be some signs that the curve may be flattened, but now is not the time to ease social distancing measures. (Newswires)

Dutch PM Rutte said schools, restaurants and gyms are to remain shut until at least April 28th. (Newswires)

 

UK/EU

ECB's Visco said that the Bank will not tolerate any impediments that hinder the efficacy of monetary policy transmission. (Newswires)

EU HICP Flash (Mar) Y/Y 0.7% vs. Exp. 0.8% (Prev. 1.2%). (Newswires)

 

COMMODITIES

US Private Inventory Crude Stocks (w/e 27th Mar) +10.5mln vs. Exp. +4.0mln (Prev. -1.2mln). (Newswires)

US and Saudi oil alliance has for now been put aside according to three sources. (Newswires)

Saudi Aramco has sent notice to oil service companies to be prepared to support increasing domestic oil output to 12mln BPD from April 1st and for the foreseeable future, according to sources. (Newswires)

OPEC members fail to unanimously agree on an emergency meeting of its economic commission board, according to four sources. (Newswires) 

 

US

Fed offered repo agreements to foreign central banks and will allow foreign central banks to use Treasury holdings to obtain dollars, while it will help broaden access for countries beyond the existing swap lines. (Newswires)

Fed's Mester (voter, hawk) said an unemployment rate above 10% is feasible because economic activity is being shut down to stop the spread of the virus, while she expects some very bad numbers for the economy but added that the situation can improve when we get to the other side. (Newswires)

Fed's Daly (non-voter, dovish) said she expects the economy to get worse before it gets better and already believes US is in a recession, while she added that what the Fed does depends on the evolution of the virus and that it is prepared to do whatever is required within its powers. (Newswires)

US President Trump is to suspend certain tariffs payments for 90-days on imports such as apparel and light trucks, although it will not include some of the high-profile tariffs including the metals tariffs and punitive tariffs on USD 360bln of imports from China. (FT) 

US President Trump administration is not on track for the new USMCA to fully go into effect as planned on 1st June, making it likely that automakers will have extra time to prepare to comply with the deal's new rules, according to Politico citing sources. (Newswires)

 

MARKET RECAP

Stocks fared weaker on Tuesday after paring earlier strength, again seemingly moving to their own rhythm as news flow remained relatively light. Many desks have attributed Monday's rally to month-end rebalancing; Citi notes that turnover was relatively low, and that relative sectors within the broader S&P 500 are sending concerning signals: cyclicals have started to underperform defensive sectors, and Citi notes that over the past year, this has preceded market corrections. Citi said it is sceptical that risk assets continue to rally once month-end is out of the way. Energy stocks (XOP, XLE) were the best performing sector after being offered heavily on Monday, alongside a reprieve in oil prices. Conagra Brands (CAG) was an outperformer after it said it would exceed tis FY guidance. Domino’s (DPZ) was offered after a poor preliminary Q1 SSS growth update. Dollar Tree (DLTR) traded lower as it pulled guidance, citing uncertainties. Airlines (UAL, AAL, DAL) had a strong day as the group moves closer to securing the latest government stimulus package. SPX -1.51% at 2587, NDX -0.96% at 7814, DJIA -1.84% at 21,917.

The TPLEX was little changed on Tuesday, excluding the long end, which was weaker by settlement. The Fed remains the main buyer in town across the curve, and similar to Monday, its completion of purchases in the belly earlier on in the session saw yields rise off their lows heading into settlement, although by no means drastically, as desks note a supply drought as gauged by lower take-up in the Fed’s Treasury purchases on Tuesday. Meanwhile, the Fed’s RRP operation continued to balloon while the regular repo ops saw miniscule take-up. The IG slate continues to let it rip, albeit less pronounced than Monday (IFR noted March as the largest volume month ever with USD 256.47bln in supply), while Israel came to the SSA market (10s, 30s, 100s). By settlement, yields were relatively unchanged, if not higher at the long end, 2s +1bps at 0.238%, 10s +3bps at 0.702%, 30s +7.5bps at 1.359%. T-note (M0) futures settled 4+ ticks lower at 138-22.

subject: Newsquawk US Market Wrap - 31st March 2020: Stock rally stalls as month-end factors fade
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

31 March 2020: Stock rally stalls as month-end factors fade

  • SNAPSHOT: Equities down, Treasuries up, Dollar down, Crude flat/up.
  • REARVIEW: Part 4 stimulus efforts being made, Trump gunning for USD 2trln infrastructure; Fed announces foreign repo agreement facility; bounce in Chicago PMI overshadowed.
  • COMING UP: Data: Japanese Tankan, Chinese Caixin Manufacturing, German Retail Sales, EZ & UK Manufacturing PMI (Final), EZ Unemployment, US Construction Spending, ISM Manufacturing. Supply: Germany

MARKET WRAP

Stocks fared weaker on Tuesday after paring earlier strength, again seemingly moving to their own rhythm as new news flow remains relatively light. Many desks have attributed Monday's rally to month-end rebalancing; Citi notes that turnover was relatively low, and that relative sectors within the broader S&P 500 are sending concerning signals: cyclicals have started to underperform defensive sectors, and Citi notes that over the past year, this has preceded market corrections. Citi said it is sceptical that risk assets continue to rally once month-end is out of the way. Energy stocks were the relative outperformer on the session, supported by the selling reprieve in oil prices. The Treasury curve was little changed, with the curve mainly dancing around to the tune of Fed purchases. Meanwhile, the USD peaked earlier in the session, before reversing course in the latter part of European trade.

CASE COUNT

WORLDWIDE CASES 846,251, DEATHS 41,482, RECOVERED 176,520.

Figures provided as of Tuesday (via worldometer website) against Monday:

  • US total cases 180,789 (prev. 163,788), death toll 3,580 (prev. 3,141).
  • ITALY total cases 105,792 (prev. 101,739), death toll 12,428 (prev. 11,591).
  • SPAIN total cases 94,417 (prev. 87,956), death toll 8,269 (prev. 7,716).
  • CHINA total cases 81,518 (prev. 81,439), death toll 3,305 (prev. 3,300).
  • GERMANY total cases 70,985 (prev. 66,885), death toll 682 (prev. 645).
  • FRANCE total cases 52,128 (prev. 44,550), death toll 3,523 (prev. 3,024).
  • UK total cases 25,150 (prev. 22,141), death toll 1,789 (prev. 1,408).
  • SWITZERLAND total cases 16,605 (prev. 15,922), death toll 433 (prev. 359).
  • NETHERLANDS total cases 12,595 (prev. 11,750), death toll 1,039 (prev. 864).
  • SOUTH KOREA total cases 9,786 (prev. 9,661), death toll 162 (prev. 158).
  • CANADA total cases 8,467 (prev. 7,448), death toll 95 (prev. 89).

Note figures are provided via worldometers thus there may be some discrepancies on figures provided against those stated from individual states.

NORTH AMERICA

STIMULUS - PART 4: White House officials have compiled lists of requests from agencies, which total around USD 600bln, sources said. The proposals reportedly include more state aid, as well as financial aid for mortgage and travel industries. US President Trump tweeted that this is the time for our long-awaited infrastructure bill, as US interest rates are at 0%; should be big and bold at USD 2trln, Trump said, focusing solely on jobs and rebuilding infrastructure. Meanwhile, Senate Majority Leader McConnell said we need to wait and see if a part 4 virus relief bill is needed, adds that pandemic-related US Treasury bonds are an 'interesting idea'.

RESTRICTIONS: US President Trump said we can save more than 1mln lives by following social distancing guidelines vigorously. President Trump also stated that there are challenging times ahead for the next 30 days and that 1mln Americans have now been tested, while he suggested that a national stay at home order was unlikely. It was elsewhere reported that US President Trump could announce a 90-day deferral of some tariff payments, but will not include those imposed on China goods; this proposal has previously been suggested.

CENTRAL BANKS

FED FACILITIES: The Fed announced the offering of repo agreements to foreign central banks; will allow foreign central banks to use Treasury holdings to obtain dollars and will help broaden access for countries beyond the existing swap lines. The announcement saw some weakness in the USD as the market reacted to yet another Fed facility to alleviate any funding pressures, a new normal in the current crisis mode.

ECB'S VISCO said that the Bank will not tolerate any impediments that hinder the efficacy of monetary policy transmission, adding that the Bank is prepared to increase the size of asset purchases and alter their composition and explore all potential options to provide support to the economy during the crisis. ECB'S HOLZMANN noted the idea behind the PEPP was to make liquidity rapidly available, rules for this were loosened to ensure enough assets were available for purchase; said rules on PEPP will be set in the future. Holzmann also said there are to be discussions on coronabonds in the ECB but declined to comment on this at present.

REST OF WORLD

G20 finance ministers, in a joint statement, said it has agreed on a road map to implement the commitments made by leaders; G20 reiterates the risk of debt vulnerabilities in low income countries. G20 financial officials have tasked relevant working groups with delivering on the roadmap by the April 15th meeting.

EUROPEAN STIMULUS: The European Commission is working on plans to raise funds for a EUR 80-100bln reinsurance scheme for countries struggling with rocketing jobless claims, the FT reported.

CHINA: PBoC adviser Ma Jun advised China to not set a 2020 GDP target given the large uncertainties, while Ma added setting a target may force China to resort to flood-like stimulus and noted that GDP growth of 4%-5% will be difficult to reach. Elsewhere, a Chinese Tax Bureau official said China is monitoring the trade situation and studying tax reduction, as well as other policies to stabilize situation, while the official added China is studying permitting more foreign firms to benefit from preferential policies such as tax cuts.

DATA

CHICAGO PMI: fell to 47.8 from 49.0, above the expected 40.0, as well as above the top end of estimates at 46.0. Pantheon note that the regional survey was already under significant pressure compared to other regional surveys due to Boeing (BA) being headquartered in Chicago, so the mid-month COVID-19 shutdown had less of a dent. The consultancy believes, however, that the floor is by no means yet in, despite this seemingly positive overshoot.

CHINESE NBS MANUFACTURING PMI (MAR) 52.0 vs. exp. 45.0 (prev. 35.7). Non-Manufacturing PMI (Mar) 52.3 vs. exp. 42.0 (prev. 29.6). Chinese Composite PMI (Mar) 53.0 (prev. 28.9). China Stats Bureau said the rebound does not mean the economy has returned to normal and March data alone cannot tell an improving trend.

EZ HICP fell by slightly more than the consensus expected due to the energy component (0.8% Y/Y, exp. 0.8%, prev. 1.2%) - and this may also present downside risks in the months ahead. The core rate also undershot expectations (1.0% Y/Y, exp. 1.1%, prev. 1.2%) due to declines in services inflation. Pantheon Macro said it was difficult to see what happens next; the Easter effect was pronounced last year, but should not be huge this year given that the holiday is in the same month as last year. But the key issue might relate to data collection, which makes next month's April data somewhat less reliable.

CRUDE

SETTLEMENT: WTI (K0) SETTLED USD 0.39 HIGHER AT USD 20,48/BBL; BRENT (M0) SETTLED USD 0.07 LOWER AT USD 26.35/BBL

Oil prices found some reprieve from Monday’s heavy selling albeit trended lower into settlement. The gains were made overnight after another train-wreck session to start the week, before paring strength as US participants arrived on Tuesday. Meanwhile, Saudi Aramco has reportedly sent notice to oil service companies to be prepared to support increasing domestic oil output to 12mln BPD from April 1st and for the foreseeable future; has also requested companies to gain resources (workforce and equipment) to increase capacity to 13mln BPD. Note that sources reported on Tuesday that OPEC members failed to unanimously agree on an emergency meeting of its economic commission board – an indication of the current level of disagreement and lack of cooperation in the group currently. Following on from Russian President Putin’s and US President Trump’s phone call on Monday, where the two reportedly agreed for the need of ministerial level meetings on the oil market, on a similar vein, the Kremlin said on Tuesday that the two also agreed there should be consultations on the oil market. Elsewhere, it was later reported by sources that the Saudi – US alliance has been put on hold for now, following reports in recent weeks that the two nations were looking to find a solution to balance the oil market after the former entered a price war with Russia. Participants now look ahead to the weekly US energy inventories, with the private data release due later on Tuesday, current expectations (bbls) see crude stocks +4.0mln, gasoline +1.9mln and distillates +1.0mln, while Cushing stocks have been indicated to be in excess of +4.0mln.

FIXED INCOME

TREASURY SETTLEMENT: T-NOTE (M0) FUTURES SETTLED 4+ TICKS LOWER AT 138-22.

The TPLEX was little changed on Tuesday, excluding the long end, which was weaker by settlement. The Fed remains the main buyer in town across the curve, and similar to Monday, its completion of purchases in the belly earlier on in the session saw yields rise off their lows heading into settlement, although by no means drastically, as desks note a supply drought as gauged by lower take-up in the Fed’s Treasury purchases on Tuesday. Meanwhile, the Fed’s RRP operation continued to balloon while the regular repo ops saw miniscule take-up. The IG slate continues to let it rip, albeit less pronounced than Monday (IFR noted March as the largest volume month ever with USD 256.47bln in supply), while Israel came to the SSA market (10s, 30s, 100s). By settlement, yields were relatively unchanged, if not higher at the long end, 2s +1bps at 0.238%, 10s +3bps at 0.702%, 30s +7.5bps at 1.359%.

EQUITIES

CLOSING LEVELS: SPX -1.51% at 2587, NDX -0.96% at 7814, DJIA -1.84% at 21,917.

SECTORS: Utilities -4.02%, Real Estate -3.26%, Financials -2.99%, Cons Stpl -1.96%, Technology -1.89%, Cons Disc -1.78%, Materials -1.43%, Industrials -1.27%, Communication Svs -0.51%, Health -0.39%, Energy +1.63%.

STOCK SPECIFICS: Energy stocks (XOP, XLE) were the best performing sector after being offered heavily on Monday, alongside a reprieve in oil prices. Conagra Brands (CAG) was an outperformer after it said it would exceed tis FY guidance. Domino’s (DPZ) was offered after a poor preliminary Q1 SSS growth update. Dollar Tree (DLTR) traded lower as it pulled guidance, citing uncertainties. Airlines (UAL, AAL, DAL) had a strong day as the group moves closer to securing the latest government stimulus package.

FOREX

DXY: The index and Greenback in general seem to have run out of steam after the former topped out fractions ahead of the 100.000 level at 99.954 on a continuation of portfolio rebalancing. Indeed, the Buck failed to glean additional impetus from less COVID-19 contagion than anticipated in the Chicago PMI or US consumer confidence holding up considerably better than feared, even though there may be worse to come when the full nCoV or more damage is done. However, as witnessed on previous occasions (no less than 6 before today in March alone) Fed measures to ease credit and funding strains have undermined the Usd to the benefit of trading partners.

GBP Notwithstanding the Dollar’s ongoing and overriding bid, the Pound appears primed to end the last day of the month, quarter and financial year with a flourish as Cable reclaims the 1.2400 handle and Eur/Gbp reverses towards 0.8800 from around 0.8968 to build on Monday’s gains through a key Fib retracement level just under 0.8900. Nothing standout in terms of positive or supportive Sterling factors, but cross flows for the end of March/Q1/fy 2019-20 may be impacting alongside the latest Fed repo facility to provide Usd liquidity, though the FIMA is designed for all foreign Central Banks and international monetary institutions to tap and is in addition to already expanded and enhanced swap lines. Moreover, Eur/Gbp bounced into the 4pm fix and trade remains whippy across the board in currencies (another other asset classes for that matter), with Cable heading back down below the round number around the same time.

JPY/CAD: The other relative G10 outperformers, or at least deriving more than others from the aforementioned US Dollar pull-back, with the Yen back above 108.00 and Loonie paring losses from nearly 1.4350.

NZD/CHF/AUD/EUR: The major laggards as the Kiwi faces stiff Aud/Nzd headwinds due to its Antipodean neighbour hanging on to a bit more of its post-Chinese PMI relief, but both well down overnight peaks. Conversely, the Franc never really got any purchase from better than expected Swiss retail sales data and remains close to 0.9650, while the Euro has not been able to reclaim 1.1000 after benign Eurozone CPI and still rising coronavirus cases/fatalities in both Spain and Italy especially.

COMMODITY FX: Supported by higher oil prices, RUB, NOK firmed. The US and Russia agreed on Monday to hold ministerial-level talks on stabilising the oil market, and there has been further chatter out of Texas, where regulators are more loudly talking about curbing supply.

BRL: Real under-performance in recent days has been attributed to a divide among lawmakers, with Bolsonaro calling for "no more quarantine" -- other health officials disagree with that approach. Some data points, like monthly jobs, has also been shelved. However, late Monday, the Brazilians passed measures to support incomes of its poorest citizens and will give monthly payments of BRL 600 for three-months, which could cost almost BRL 50bln.

Daily FX Wrap: US consumer confidence and PMIs provide some pain relief
content:
GBP

Notwithstanding the Dollar’s ongoing and overriding bid, the Pound appears primed to end the last day of the month, quarter and financial year with a flourish as Cable reclaims the 1.2400 handle and Eur/Gbp reverses towards 0.8800 from around 0.8968 to build on Monday’s gains through a key Fib retracement level just under 0.8900. Nothing standout in terms of positive or supportive Sterling factors, but cross flows for the end of March/Q1/fy 2019-20 may be impacting alongside the latest Fed repo facility to provide Usd liquidity, though the FIMA is designed for all foreign Central Banks and international monetary institutions to tap and is in addition to already expanded and enhanced swap lines. Moreover, Eur/Gbp bounced into the 4pm fix and trade remains whippy across the board in currencies (another other asset classes for that matter), with Cable heading back down below the round number around the same time.

DXY

The index and Greenback in general seem to have run out of steam after the former topped out fractions ahead of the 100.000 level at 99.954 on a continuation of portfolio rebalancing. Indeed, the Buck failed to glean additional impetus from less COVID-19 contagion than anticipated in the Chicago PMI or US consumer confidence holding up considerably better than feared, even though there may be worse to come when the full nCoV or more damage is done. However, as witnessed on previous occasions (no less than 6 before today in March alone) Fed measures to ease credit and funding strains have undermined the Usd to the benefit of trading partners.

NOK/SEK

The Norwegian Crown has been on the front foot for the most part as firmer crude prices coupled with the Norges Bank preannouncing bigger daily purchases for next month helped the Nok rally against the grain and rebound from almost 11.6700 to 11.4250 vs the Eur, but its Swedish peer has caught up as Eur/Sek retreats through 11.0000 from just over 11.1200 at one stage, partly on Euro weakness independently.

JPY/CAD

The other relative G10 outperformers, or at least deriving more than others from the aforementioned US Dollar pull-back, with the Yen back above 108.00 and Loonie paring losses from nearly 1.4350 by almost 200 pips.

NZD/CHF/AUD/EUR

The major laggards as the Kiwi faces stiff Aud/Nzd headwinds due to its Antipodean neighbour hanging on to a bit more of its post-Chinese PMI relief, but both well down overnight peaks. Conversely, the Franc never really got any purchase from better than expected Swiss retail sales data and remains close to 0.9650, while the Euro has not been able to reclaim 1.1000 after benign Eurozone CPI and still rising coronavirus cases/fatalities in both Spain and Italy especially.

subject: US stocks open lower; energy names stand out after US and Russia talk about stabilising markets
content:
• FUTURES: US index futures were lower ahead of the cash equity open, with the ES having given up gains of around +1%. Futures were supported overnight after Chinese PMI data staged a rebound, although analysts point out that the manufacturing new export orders sub-index remained sub-50, highlighting the challenges from falling overseas demand. April's report will be key to see how it captures the deterioration in the rest of the world. Futures have seen a bounce this morning on news that the Fed was to offer foreign central banks repo operations; some desks have said the implications are limited for equities given the number of monetary measures announced in March (seventh liquidity facility announced this month).
  • SECTORS: Energy names are higher on reports that the US and Russia are to hold ministerial-level discussions to stabilise the oil market. All other major sectors are negative with utilities and staples leading the losses.
  • US STOCKS NEWS: Airlines are mixed/higher (AAL, UAL, DAL, LUV, JBLU, ALK, SAVE), after the Treasury released guidelines on how it will provide grants and loans. JNJ is higher after it signed a deal with Moderna to produce large quantities of coronavirus vaccines. AAPL higher after supplier Japan Display reportedly raises USD 200mln of funding from Apple via customer purchase agreements, sources say. Gap (GPS) is lower after it said it expects stores to remain shut for longer. AMZN, GOOG, FB are lower, reportedly seeking a six-month deferment of Indian digital tax, sources say. CAG higher after its earnings report saw the co. raise 2020 guidance. In energy, PXD and PE are up after formally asking Texas regulators to consider curbing oil output. CCL is heavily lower after it suspended dividend payments and share repurchases, and also expects a net loss in FY20.   
  • MONTH-END: Many analysts attributed Monday's rally to month-end rebalancing; Citi notes that turnover was relatively low, and that relative sectors within the broader S&P 500 are sending concerning signals: cyclicals have started to underperform defensive sectors, and Citi notes that over the past year, this has preceded market corrections. The bank also observes that the most COVID-impacted sectors have also begun to underperform the broader index, which has been a tactical leading indicator in recent months; Citi says it is sceptical that risk assets continue to rally once month-end is out of the way.
  • FED QE: Some desks have argued that the Fed being in the market has also provided a source of support for the risk complex. As such, it is worth keeping the NY Fed's daily schedule of purchases to hand. 
  • LIQUIDITY: Nomura quants say investors are backing away from overblown pessimism following global central bank actions. Ahead, Nomura says one of two things are likely: either global stock markets experience a double dip in the course of their realignment with reality, or they become more liquidity-driven with an unusually heavy dependence on the actions of central banks. More immediately, Nomura warns that liquidity in equity futures markets has been slow to recover, and this lack of liquidity means that futures markets are likely to remain volatile, with implications for the stability of trends in cash equity prices as well. "The effect may be temporary, but it appears that equity futures are being priced at a discount in markets where liquidity is relatively lacking while being priced at a premium in markets where liquidity is still relatively plentiful, perhaps partly as a result of how the coronavirus outbreak has shaken up market-making activity."

subject: PRIMER: US March Consumer Confidence released at 1500 BST/1000 ET; likely to show a big fall
content:
• Consensus looks for 110.00 from a prior 130.7 (range 87.4 to 122.0), hit by covid disruptions. 
  • Oxford Economics notes that the cut-off date for respondents to the survey was likely around mid-month, before the widening number of lock downs and surge in layoffs across the country. "This will limit the decline in confidence in March, but a much steeper decline is in store for April."  
  • Much focus will be on the labour market metrics, ahead of Thursday's weekly jobless claims data. In the February report, the Conference Board data showed the differential between jobs 'plentiful' and 'hard to get' was at 29.8, narrowing from 35.3 - this is likely to narrow further in the months ahead, analysts have said. Last month, the CB also noted that consumers' outlook for the labour market was mixed, with the proportion expecting more jobs declined slightly from 16.5 to 16.2, but those anticipating fewer jobs in the months ahead also decreased, from 12.9 to 11.1.

Fixed and FX latest: bonds still on the bounce, but Buck stalls
content: Hardly any market reaction to stale Canadian data, but impending US releases may warrant some attention given their more timely nature and the Wall Street open will provide some extra impetus in the meantime. However, Gilts have edged higher again to briefly trade over parity at 136.70 vs 135.30 at the other extreme, while Bunds and USTs continue to chip away at losses as EU equities and US stock futures waver. Elsewhere, the Dollar dipped on the back of yet another Fed repo facility, this time aimed at foreign Central Banks in possession of Treasuries that can be used as collateral for overnight funds via the FIMA liquidity op. The DXY is holding just above 99.500 vs 99.954 at best, so far.

subject: PRIMER: Canada January GDP released at 1330 BST/0830 ET; will likely be ignored
content:
• Pre-virus data, expected to show monthly GDP rising 0.1% M/M against a prior 0.3%. Canadian bank RBC says it is backward looking, and is already looking to other data points.  
  • RBC says that indicators like the CFIB Business Barometer suggest the March GDP data could see a monthly (non-annualised) decline of around 1.5% due to cirus disruptions. "Such a result would suggest a worse outcome than our already downgraded -3.0% (annualised) GDP forecast for Q1. Additionally, Wednesday's manufacturing PMI is likely to show a record low below the December-2015 print of 47.5 (previous 51.8), RBC notes. 
  • Fiscal measures are more likely to garner more attention at the moment. On Monday, Canada expanded its 75% wage subsidy to include large companies.  
  • Key CAD levels: Support 1.4083 and 1.4012;  resistance 1.4187 and 1.4230.

Newsquawk Daily US Opening News - 31st March 2020
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Sentiment has generally been upbeat, but US futures are deteriorating as US players enter the market
  • Chinese Manufacturing and Non-Manufacturing PMI topped estimates and the Composite PMI also printed in expansion territory
  • Some downplayed the data given that it was a recovery from the prior month’s record low base and with China’s stats bureau warning the rebound does not mean the economy has returned to normal
  • WHO official said coronavirus epidemic is far from over in Asia and the focus of the epidemic is now in Europe but will likely shift to other regions
  • FX sees the USD firmer, to the detriment of G10 peers, but DXY still capped by the 100.00 mark
  • Looking ahead, highlights include Canadian GDP, US Chicago PMI, US Consumer Confidence, APIs

CORONAVIRUS UPDATE

WHO official said coronavirus epidemic is far from over in Asia and the focus of the epidemic is now in Europe but will likely shift to other regions. The official also stated that measures to reduce transmission will not remove risks as long as the pandemic continues and that steps to reduce transmission can buy time to prepare for large-scale community transmission, while the official added that there are more than 50 candidate vaccines for coronavirus and several trials are ongoing. (Newswires)

US President Trump said we can save more than 1mln lives by following social distancing guidelines vigorously. President Trump also stated that there are challenging times ahead for the next 30 days and that 1mln Americans have now been tested, while he suggested that a national stay at home order was pretty unlikely. (Newswires)

US has recorded 575 new coronavirus deaths on Monday, the most in a single day of the outbreak. 3,004 total deaths so far, according to CNN's Sciutto citing CNN Health - NOT OFFICIAL DATA. (Twitter)

Mainland China reported 48 additional cases and 1 additional death on March 30th vs. 31 additional cases and 4 deaths on March 29th, to bring the total number of confirmed cases in mainland China to 81518 and death toll at 3305. (Newswires)

Spain's coronavirus cases stand at 94,417 (Prev. 85,195), according to the Health Ministry; deaths at 8189 (Prev. 7340). (Newswires)

World Bank sees 2020 Developing East Asia and Pacific Region growth to slow to 2.1% in baseline scenario due to coronavirus and deteriorate to -0.5% in lower case scenario, while it sees China growth to slow to 2.3% in baseline scenario and to 0.1% in lower case scenario. (Newswires)

Head of Germany's Robert Koch Institute says that they are optimistic about the flattening of the infection curve and the optimism is still justified and will be clearer after Easter. (Newswires)

ASIA

Asia equity markets were mostly higher (before trimming some gains) as the region took its cue from the gains on Wall St following recent global stimulus efforts and with sentiment also underpinned by an improvement in the latest Chinese PMI figures. ASX 200 (-2%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.9%) were lifted from the open with early outperformance in Australia led by the largest weighted financials sector and with sentiment also boosted after yesterday’s record AUD 130bln stimulus announcement, while Japanese exporters initially benefitted from a weaker currency, although both indices then gave up the gains amid Q1-end rebalancing and amid some doubts regarding the Chinese data. Hang Seng (+1.3%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.1%) conformed to the early constructive tone following encouraging Chinese PMI data in which headline Manufacturing and Non-Manufacturing PMI topped estimates and the Composite PMI also printed in expansion territory. However, gains in the mainland were somewhat limited as some downplayed the data given that it was a recovery from the prior month’s record low base and with China’s stats bureau warning the rebound does not mean the economy has returned to normal and that this month’s data alone cannot determine an improving trend. Finally, 10yr JGBs were pressured in a continuation of the pullback from the 153.00 level, with demand subdued by the early upbeat tone in risky assets and following weaker results at the 2yr JGB auction.

PBoC injected CNY 20bln via 7-Day Reverse Repos at a rate of 2.20% vs. Prev. 2.20% (Newswires) PBoC set USD/CNY mid-point at 7.0851 vs. Exp. 7.0860 (Prev. 7.0447)

Chinese NBS Manufacturing PMI (Mar) 52.0 vs. Exp. 45.0 (Prev. 35.7). Chinese Non-Manufacturing PMI (Mar) 52.3 vs. Exp. 42.0 (Prev. 29.6) Chinese Composite PMI (Mar) 53.0 (Prev. 28.9)

China Stats Bureau said the rebound does not mean the economy has returned to normal and March data alone cannot tell improving trend. (Newswires)

PBoC adviser Ma Jun advised China to not set a 2020 GDP target given the large uncertainties, while Ma added setting a target may force China to resort to flood-like stimulus and noted that GDP growth of 4%-5% will be difficult to reach. (Newswires)

China tax bureau official said China is monitoring the trade situation and studying tax reduction, as well as other policies to stabilize situation, while the official added China is studying permitting more foreign firms to benefit from preferential policies such as tax cuts. (Newswires)

Japanese Industrial Production (Feb P) M/M 0.4% vs. Exp. 0.1% (Prev. 1.0%). (Newswires) Japanese Industrial Production (Feb P) Y/Y -4.7% vs. Exp. -4.9% (Prev. -2.3%) Japanese Industrial Production Forecast for March at -5.3% and April at 7.5%. Japanese Retail Sales (Feb) M/M 0.6% vs. Exp. -1.5% (Prev. 0.6%) Japanese Retail Sales (Feb) Y/Y 1.7% vs. Exp. -1.2% (Prev. -0.4%)

Japanese government official said manufacturers' output forecasts for March and April do not fully reflect developments of coronavirus outbreak, while the official added that the outlook for industrial production is to remain severe for the time being. (Newswires)

Japan's GPIF is to raise foreign bond allocation target to 25% (Prev. 15%) and raises upper limitation of investments in foreign bonds to 31%. Allocation to domestic bonds has been lowered to 25% from 35%. (Newswires)

Japan's senior ruling party official says that if necessary, the government should deploy 2nd and 3rd batches of stimulus measures. (Newswires)

UK/EU

ECB's Visco says that the Bank will not tolerate any impediments that hinder the efficacy of monetary policy transmission, adding that the Bank is prepared to increase the size of asset purchases and alter their composition and explore all potential options to provide support to the economy during the crisis. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

North Korea appears to have created a new foreign ministry department with the aim of handling negotiations with the US, according to Yonhap. (Yonhap)

US has called for transitional government in Venezuela made up of opposition and some members of President Maduro’s socialist party, according to a document. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

European equities trade on a firmer footing once again (Eurostoxx 50 +0.3%) as sentiment remains upbeat alongside quarter-end rebalancing flows and post-Chinese PMI metrics, albeit stocks have drifted off highs. On the data front, price garnered some support from the last survey data out of China in which headline Manufacturing and Non-Manufacturing PMI topped estimates and the Composite PMI also printed in expansion territory. However, it is worth noting that some desks have downplayed the data given that it was a recovery from the prior month’s record low base and with China’s stats bureau warning the rebound does not mean the economy has returned to normal and that this month’s data alone cannot determine an improving trend. In terms of sector specifics, energy names sit near the top of the pile in a bounce-back from some of the declines yesterday with WTI now back above USD 21/bbl and Shell (+4.0%) shares shrugging off expectations of a USD 400-800mln Q1 impairment charge and weak refining margins. Elsewhere, travel and leisure names have also seen support during today’s session as hopes continue to be pinned on government support measures, albeit, from a UK standpoint, Times’ Swinford noted comments from Transport Secretary Shapps that the “UK government is attempting to find the right solution for airlines”, something which Swinford inferred as meaning that it “doesn’t sound like a big bailout is coming”. The main theme in the pre-market was largely centered around the suspension of buybacks and dividends (details of which can be found in the European equity opening news) with particular focus on the UK banking sector with the latest reports via Sky News suggesting that the Prudential Regulation Authority will, on Tuesday or Wednesday, state that Barclays, HSBC, Lloyds and RBS will not be paying dividends as part of FY results. Notable individual movers include Imperial Brands (+12.4%) after signing a new revolving credit facility of EUR 3.5bln and noting no material impact on group performance, Bayer (+2.0%) has reached a settlement with US plaintiffs and WPP (+6.9%) are firmer despite suspending its buyback, dividend and outlook, whilst noting that it maintains a strong balance sheet.

Tesla (TSLA) - Credit Suisse revises Tesla Q1 delivery forecast to around 75-80k units vs. Prev. 94k units

FX

USD - The Buck has extended gains vs major counterparts, albeit to varying degrees as a sharp rebound in Chinese PMIs, some consolidation in crude and remaining asset rebalancing flows for the final trading session of March, Q1 and the current financial year help some rival currencies to resist the Greenback’s advances. However, the DXY looks more assured around 99.500 and certainly back on the 99.000 handle within a 99.694-99.100 range, and could continue its recovery towards resistance at 99.915 (prior 2020 high before the psychological 100.000 mark was breached precisely one month later on March 20 when the index hit 102.999).

NOK - The G10 outlier and outperformer, partly due to the aforementioned bounce in oil prices, but mainly as the Norges Bank plans to jack up foreign currency sales against the Norwegian Krona to the equivalent of Nok2 bn per day in April from Nok1.6 bn this month and only a quarter of the new daily total in February. Eur/Nok is hovering just above 11.5100, but has been under 11.5000 in contrast to Eur/Sek flat-lining between 11.1040-0610 parameters.

CAD/AUD/NZD/GBP/EUR/JPY/CHF - Firmer or more stable crude is also providing the Loonie with some underlying support around 1.4200 vs its US peer, while the Aussie and Kiwi are both holding off overnight pre-Chinese PMI flash crash lows of 0.6080 and 0.5948, though down from best levels reached (0.6200+ and 0.6037 respectively) when the headline prints exceeded consensus and regained 50+ growth rather than deep contraction levels. Elsewhere, the Pound has lost its grasp of 1.2400, but faring better against the Euro circa 0.8900 as the single currency retreats through 1.1000 vs the Buck on soft Eurozone inflation and the ongoing nCoV spread in Spain. Note, hefty Eur/Usd option expiries do not seem likely to impact at this stage, but for the record there are several ranging from 1 to 1.6 bn rolling off from 1.1000 to the 1.1100 strike and beyond. Meanwhile, the Yen and Franc are towards the bottom of 108.70-107.75 and 0.9649-0.9581 bands and hindered by safe-haven outflows, with the latter not deriving any support from considerably firmer than forecast Swiss retail sales.

EM - Some respite for the Rouble after a call between US President Trump and his Russian counterpart Putin aimed at stopping the dispute with Saudi Arabia over the price of oil and market share, but little joy for the Lira even though the CBRT has rolled out more liquidity provisions for Turkish banks.

FIXED

Gilts are gradually paring more of their early DMO issuance related losses and unwinding losses relative to core counterparts at fresh Liffe intraday highs of 136.47 (-22 ticks vs -139 ticks at one stage), as the FTSE drifts back from best levels alongside EU equivalents awaiting the return of US market participants for the run in to month end. However, bonds are still on the back foot amidst the last asset portfolio and balance sheet adjustments for the final trading day of Q1 and some potential market moving macro releases in the form of Chicago PMI and Conference Board consumer confidence.

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent front-month futures experience consolidation from the prior session’s hefty losses, in which prices tumbled to their lowest points in almost 20 years. The former outperforms on the prospect of potential US-Russia cooperation in the energy markets to stem the rotting prices. US President Trump conducted a phone call with his Russian counterpart yesterday with Kremlin noting that this was at the request of the US. The leaders agreed on the need for stability in the energy markets, albeit no further details were released. WTI front-month contracts have reclaimed USD 21/bbl to the upside having yesterday printed a base at around USD 19.30/bbl, whilst Brent touched a multi-year low at ~ USD 21.60/bbl, with prices now nearer to USD 23.50/bbl. Elsewhere, spot gold trades subdued amid a firmer USD and with portfolio rebalancing also in the fray. The yellow metal hovers just above the 1600/oz mark having hit an overnight peak at USD 1626/oz. Meanwhile, copper prices remain supported by the strong China NBS manufacturing PMIs which rose back into expansionary territory from last month’s detrimental print. Copper gains a firmer footing above USD 2/lb ahead of resistance at 2.5/lb from a technical standpoint.

OPEC March crude production survey: JCB sees OPEC crude output rising by 170k BPD to 27.92mln BPD - increases led by Saudi raising production by 370k BPD to 10.15mln BPD. (Newswires)

subject: ECB's Holzmann notes the idea behind the PEPP was to make liquidity rapibly available, rules for this were loosended to ensure enough assets were available for purchase; rules on PEPP will be set in the future.
content: • Are to be discussions are corona-bonds in the ECB, declines to comment on this at present.
analysis_details:
• PEPP - Pandemic Emergency Purchase Programme
  • Last week, reports noted that ECB's Lagarde asked EZ Finance Ministers yesterday to seriously consider a one-off joint debt issue of coronabonds, according to officials. Lagarde suggested that the joint issuance would be on top of the use of the bailout fund. The joint issuance plan was opposed by Northern European nations, however, support did come from beyond southern states. Report also added at the time that joint debt issuance has not been discussed by the Eurogroup at this stageEarlier last week, French Finance Minister Le Maire said there is no Eurogroup consensus on the use of coronabonds, adding that the ESM should be able to be used in the coming weeks, it is the time to use it

  • In addition, this ONS data encapsulates people who died outside of hospitals with the coronavirus listed as their primary cause of death
  • On this, some data vendors/journalists are extrapolating that the UK death toll is now in excess of 1.5k; but, this must be caveated as not being complete as is incorporates the most recent daily update from hospitals in the UK as well as this dated reading from ONS -  as such, the true number at present is likely to be higher

subject: Gilts correct lower and carry on, Short Sterling strip steeper
content: UK bonds returned to Liffe around ½ point down from Monday’s 136.69 close and saw a fleeting upturn to 136.23 before the DMO announced a revised issuance remit for next month aimed at raising Gbp45 bn in addition to auctions already scheduled for the 1st and 2nd on April. Understandably, bears pounced and smashed the 10 year debt future down to a deeper low at 135.30 before some short covering alongside Bunds that hit a fresh Eurex base of 172.33 against the backdrop of rising EU equities into month end (possibly on residual asset portfolio rebalancing). Meanwhile, STIR contracts are straddling parity with the curve steeper within a +2 to -3.5 tick range at the extremes.

subject: Japan's senior ruling party official says that if necessary, the government should deploy 2nd and 3rd batches of stimulus measures
analysis_details: • YESTERDAY - Japan's ruling party has proposed a JPY 60trln stimulus package which could include direct government spending of around JPY 20trln. The proposals will be submitted to PM Abe on Tuesday. Japan will also ramp up government bond issuance by USD JPY 16trln to fund virus stimulus, sources said, with the maturity issuance will be increase excluding 40yr bonds, I/L and liquidity supplying bonds; 6-mth Treasury Discount Bills could be issued, sources added. On Saturday, PM Abe said that the government will compile a stimulus package in about ten days, which will include cash payouts to households and a scheme for private institutions to lend to some businesses at 0% interest rate. Elsewhere, Japan's cabinet secretary has said that the country could be moving towards a 'national emergency' declaration.

subject: PRIMER: EZ inflation released at 1000BST/0500ET; declining petrol prices likely to weigh on headline inflation
content:
• Consensus looks for headline Y/Y CPI to fall to 0.8% from 1.2%, core is seen at 1.2% vs. prev. 1.3% with super-core forecast at 1.1% vs. prev. 1.2%
  • By way of regional proxies, yesterday’s German release came in as expected with Y/Y inflation at 1.4% and a monthly rate of 0.1%. In France, Y/Y saw a marked drop off to 0.6% from 1.4% with M/M remaining flat, whilst Spain saw price pressures ease to 0.1% on a Y/Y basis from 0.7% (consensus looked for 0.4%)
  • Heading into the EZ-wide release, analysts at RBC note that the headline will largely be guided by declines in petrol prices with prices falling 2.6% in March compared to 2019 levels. However, the impact from some of this could be offset by the fallout from supply chain disruptions
  • That said, today’s release will likely pass with little in the way of fanfare given the recent stimulus measures undertaken by the Bank, which has left some questioning how much fire power the Governing Council has left in its arsenal

subject: Daily European Equity Opening News
content:
31st March 2020

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0200CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BSTT/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asia equity markets were mostly higher as the region took its cue from the gains on Wall St following recent global stimulus efforts and with sentiment also underpinned by an improvement in the latest Chinese PMI figures. ASX 200 (-2.9%) and Nikkei 225 (-1.2%) were lifted from the open with early outperformance in Australia led by the largest weighted financials sector and with sentiment also boosted after yesterday’s record AUD 130bln stimulus announcement, while Japanese exporters initially benefitted from a weaker currency, although both indices then gave up the gains amid Q1-end rebalancing and amid some doubts regarding the Chinese data. Hang Seng (+0.5%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.4%) conformed to the early constructive tone following encouraging Chinese PMI data in which headline Manufacturing and Non-Manufacturing PMI topped estimates and the Composite PMI also printed in expansion territory. However, gains in the mainland were somewhat limited as some downplayed the data which merely showed a recovery from the prior month’s record low base and with China’s stats bureau warning the rebound does not mean the economy has returned to normal and that this month’s data alone cannot determine an improving trend.

FTSE 100

Shell (RDSA LN) – Co. has pulled out of a major US LNG export plant under developement amid the energy price crash. (Newswires)

BP (BP/ LN) – CEO said the group will not cut jobs over the next three months. (Newswires)

Hammerson (HMSO LN) – Analysts believe that the lower share price could make the Co. an attractive takeover target. (Newswires)

UK Supermarkets - Cos such as Tesco (TSCO LN), Sainsbury's (SBRY LN), Asda (WMT) and Morrisons (MRW LN) are set to benefit from a one-year exemption from business rates despite remaining open, something  which could provide the sector with a GBP 3bln tax break. (Times)

UK Banks - Institutional investors are reported to have acknowledged that they will have to accept dividend payments being halted given the uncertainty facing the sector. (Times) Separately, research by Fideres suggests that Banks could face losses in excess of GBP 15bln on loans that are backed by leveraged buyouts and other highly geared transactions. (Times) Meanwhile, sources anticipate the Prudential Regulation Authority will, on Tuesday or Wednesday, state that Barclays (BARC LN), HSBC (HSBA LN), Lloyds (LLOY LN) and RBS (RBS LN) will not be paying dividends as part of FY results. (Sky News)

UK Insurance Names – Cos are tightening their business coverage terms and conditions to ensure the coronavirus, and anything related to it, is excluded. (FT)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

Aston Martin (AML LN) – Co. are to furlough some workers as is appropriate. Are to raise GBP 536mln via an equity offering; featuring GBP 171mln of private placement of shares to Lawrence Stroll of the Yew Tree Consortium. Additionally, Lawrence Stroll is to join the Co. as Executive Chairman on April 20th. (Newswires)

subject: Newsquawk Daily European Opening News - 31st March 2020
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

·        Asian equity markets were mostly higher (before trimming some gains) as the region took its cue from the gains on Wall St and Chinese PMI figures

·        Chinese Manufacturing and Non-Manufacturing PMI topped estimates and the Composite PMI also printed in expansion territory

·        Some downplayed the data given that it was a recovery from the prior month’s record low base and with China’s stats bureau warning the rebound does not mean the economy has returned to normal

·        DXY remained firmer after having reclaimed the 99.00 level to the upside, benefitting from weakness in major counterparts

·        WHO official said coronavirus epidemic is far from over in Asia and the focus of the epidemic is now in Europe but will likely shift to other regions

·        US Congress was looking at additional measures it could take with House Democrats discussing increasing payments to low and middle-income earners

·        Looking ahead, highlights include UK GDP, German Unemployment, EZ CPI, Canadian GDP, US Chicago PMI, US Consumer Confidence, APIs, supply from Italy

CORONAVIRUS UPDATE

WHO official said coronavirus epidemic is far from over in Asia and the focus of the epidemic is now in Europe but will likely shift to other regions. The official also stated that measures to reduce transmission will not remove risks as long as the pandemic continues and that steps to reduce transmission can buy time to prepare for large-scale community transmission, while the official added that there are more than 50 candidate vaccines for coronavirus and several trials are ongoing. (Newswires)

US President Trump said we can save more than 1mln lives by following social distancing guidelines vigorously. President Trump also stated that there are challenging times ahead for the next 30 days and that 1mln Americans have now been tested, while he suggested that a national stay at home order was pretty unlikely. (Newswires)

US Congress was looking at additional measures it could take with House Democrats discussing increasing payments to low and middle-income earners, while there were also comments from House Speaker Pelosi that a fourth coronavirus relief bill will include infrastructure, like broadband and water safety. (Newswires)

US CDC said COVID-19 cases rose to 140,904 (prev. 122,653, +15%) and the death toll increased to 2,405 (prev. 2,112).

Italy COVID-19 cases rose to 101,739 (prev. 97,689) and death toll increased to 11,591 (prev. 10,779). There were also reports the Italian government will be extending lockdown measures until "Easter April 12th" according to the Health Minister. (Newswires)

UK COVID-19 cases rose to 22,141 (prev. 19,522) and death toll rose to 1,408 (prev. 1,228), while UK Chief Scientific Advisor believes UK is tracking along the same path as France and believes hospital admissions will worsen, but have no accelerated, rising by 1,000 per day. (Newswires)

Mainland China reported 48 additional cases and 1 additional death on March 30th vs. 31 additional cases and 4 deaths on March 29th, to bring the total number of confirmed cases in mainland China to 81518 and death toll at 3305. (Newswires)

G20 trade minister statement called for international community to step up efforts and will guard against profiteering, as well as unjustified price increases, while it also noted they will continue to work to create stable trade and investment. (Newswires)

World Bank sees 2020 Developing East Asia and Pacific Region growth to slow to 2.1% in baseline scenario due to coronavirus and deteriorate to -0.5% in lower case scenario, while it sees China growth to slow to 2.3% in baseline scenario and to 0.1% in lower case scenario. (Newswires)

ASIA

Asia equity markets were mostly higher (before trimming some gains) as the region took its cue from the gains on Wall St following recent global stimulus efforts and with sentiment also underpinned by an improvement in the latest Chinese PMI figures. ASX 200 (-2.9%) and Nikkei 225 (-1.2%) were lifted from the open with early outperformance in Australia led by the largest weighted financials sector and with sentiment also boosted after yesterday’s record AUD 130bln stimulus announcement, while Japanese exporters initially benefitted from a weaker currency, although both indices then gave up the gains amid Q1-end rebalancing and amid some doubts regarding the Chinese data. Hang Seng (+0.5%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.4%) conformed to the early constructive tone following encouraging Chinese PMI data in which headline Manufacturing and Non-Manufacturing PMI topped estimates and the Composite PMI also printed in expansion territory. However, gains in the mainland were somewhat limited as some downplayed the data given that it was a recovery from the prior month’s record low base and with China’s stats bureau warning the rebound does not mean the economy has returned to normal and that this month’s data alone cannot determine an improving trend. Finally, 10yr JGBs were pressured in a continuation of the pullback from the 153.00 level, with demand subdued by the early upbeat tone in risky assets and following weaker results at the 2yr JGB auction.

PBoC injected CNY 20bln via 7-Day Reverse Repos at a rate of 2.20% vs. Prev. 2.20% (Newswires) PBoC set USD/CNY mid-point at 7.0851 vs. Exp. 7.0860 (Prev. 7.0447)

Chinese NBS Manufacturing PMI (Mar) 52.0 vs. Exp. 45.0 (Prev. 35.7). Chinese Non-Manufacturing PMI (Mar) 52.3 vs. Exp. 42.0 (Prev. 29.6) Chinese Composite PMI (Mar) 53.0 (Prev. 28.9)

China Stats Bureau said the rebound does not mean the economy has returned to normal and March data alone cannot tell improving trend. (Newswires)

PBoC adviser Ma Jun advised China to not set a 2020 GDP target given the large uncertainties, while Ma added setting a target may force China to resort to flood-like stimulus and noted that GDP growth of 4%-5% will be difficult to reach. (Newswires)

FX

In FX markets, the DXY remained firmer after having reclaimed the 99.00 level to the upside and with the greenback also benefiting from weakness in its transatlantic counterparts as a bout of volatility was seen across the FX majors heading into the key Chinese PMI data, in which EUR/USD fell about 50 pips and GBP/USD slipped around 140 pips in a matter of minutes through the 1.1000 and 1.2300 levels respectively, before paring the majority of the slump shortly after. Elsewhere, USD/JPY reclaimed the 108.00 handle and JPY-crosses were also lifted on the early safe-haven outflows, while antipodeans were marginally higher after having reversed the intraday mini flash crash and following better than expected Australian Private Sector Credit, as well as the encouraging Chinese PMI releases.

Australian Private Sector Credit (Feb) M/M 0.4% vs. Exp. 0.2% (Prev. 0.4%). (Newswires) Australian Private Sector Credit (Feb) Y/Y 2.8% vs. Exp. 2.6% (Prev. 2.5%) New Zealand ANZ Business Confidence (Mar) -63.5 vs. Exp. -24.1 (Prev. -19.4) New Zealand ANZ Activity Outlook (Mar) -26.7 (Prev. 12)

COMMODITIES

Commodities were mostly higher amid the mostly constructive risk tone and following the better than expected Chinese activity data, which provided much needed reprieve for WTI crude prices after having recently slipped to its lowest in 18 years. Nonetheless, prices climbed back above the USD 21/bbl level in Asia trade amid the encouraging data and signs of US and Russia willingness to come to the table, but with upside restricted as Saudi Arabia remains steadfast and plans to boost exports by 600k bpd in May. Elsewhere, gold prices were subdued with the precious metal dampened by a firmer greenback, while copper prices were lifted from the rebound in Chinese PMI data.

GEOPOLITICS

Libyan National Army said a Turkish plane was shot down south of Tripoli after taking off from Maitika Airport. (Newswires)

US

The TPLEX bull-steepened despite firmer risk appetite and corporate supply. The T-Note reached its highs not long after the US cash equity open as the Fed continued its ramped-up asset purchases, completing its belly purchases earlier on. However, another deluge of corporate supply to start the week, including Oracle (ORCL) with a USD 20bln 6-parter from the 5-year up to the 40-year maturity, weighed somewhat on duration in the latter part of the session; IFR noted there are at least 12 High Grade primary issuers on Monday for a week that looks set to break records again. Furthermore, the repo operations continue to see minimal demand with the GC rate still trading close to zero, while the reverse repo operation sees continued blockbuster demand, supporting the lack of collateral supply thesis and thus the bull-steepener on Monday. By settlement, 2s -3bps at 0.22%, 10s -6.5bps at 0.68%, 30s -3.5bps 1.30%; front-end bills have risen back into positive territory after moving into negative for the first time ever last week; 3-month USD Libor-OIS remains wide at 136bps. T-note (M0) futures settled 18 ticks higher at 138-26+.

Fed's Bostic (non-voter) said the Fed is looking to see in the coming weeks whether its existing programmes will prove adequate. (Newswires)

subject: ASIA-PAC MARKET WRAP: Recent stimulus efforts and rebound in Chinese PMI data buoyed Asia stocks, although some of the gains were later pared on Q1-end rebalancing and China data pessimism
content: Asia equity markets were mostly higher as the region took its cue from the gains on Wall St following recent global stimulus efforts and with sentiment also underpinned by an improvement in the latest Chinese PMI figures. ASX 200 (-2.9%) and Nikkei 225 (-1.2%) were lifted from the open with early outperformance in Australia led by the largest weighted financials sector and with sentiment also boosted after yesterday’s record AUD 130bln stimulus announcement, while Japanese exporters initially benefitted from a weaker currency, although both indices then gave up the gains amid Q1-end rebalancing and amid some doubts regarding the Chinese data. Hang Seng (+0.5%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.4%) conformed to the early constructive tone following encouraging Chinese PMI data in which headline Manufacturing and Non-Manufacturing PMI topped estimates and the Composite PMI also printed in expansion territory. However, gains in the mainland were somewhat limited as some downplayed the data which merely showed a recovery from the prior month’s record low base and with China’s stats bureau warning the rebound does not mean the economy has returned to normal and that this month’s data alone cannot determine an improving trend. Finally, 10yr JGBs were pressured in a continuation of the pullback from the 153.00 level, with demand subdued by the early upbeat tone in risky assets and following weaker results at the 2yr JGB auction.

ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Recent stimulus efforts and rebound in Chinese PMI data buoys Asia stocks
content:
Asia equity markets are higher across the board as the region takes it cue from the gains on Wall St following recent global stimulus efforts and with sentiment also underpinned by an improvement in the latest Chinese PMI figures. ASX 200 (+1.4%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.6%) were lifted from the open with early outperformance in Australia led by the largest weighted financials sector and with sentiment also boosted after yesterday’s record AUD 130bln stimulus announcement, while Japanese exporters benefit from a weaker currency and encouraging data including Industrial Production and Retail Sales. Hang Seng (+1.4%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.6%) also conform to the constructive tone following encouraging Chinese PMI data in which headline Manufacturing and Non-Manufacturing PMI topped estimates and the Composite PMI also printed in expansion territory. However, gains in the mainland are somewhat limited as some downplayed the data which merely showed a recovery from the prior month’s record low base and with China’s stats bureau warning the rebound does not mean the economy has returned to normal and that this month’s data alone cannot determine an improving trend.

In FX markets, DXY remains firmer after having reclaimed the 99.00 level to the upside and with the greenback also benefiting from weakness in its transatlantic counterparts as a bout of volatility was seen across the FX majors heading into the key Chinese PMI data, in which EUR/USD fell about 50 pips and GBP/USD slipped around 140 pips in a matter of minutes through the 1.1000 and 1.2300 levels respectively, before paring the majority of the slump shortly after. Elsewhere, USD/JPY reclaimed the 108.00 handle and JPY-crosses are also lifted on the safe-haven outflows, while antipodeans are marginally higher after having reversed the intraday mini flash crash and following better than expected Australian Private Sector Credit, as well as the Chinese PMI releases.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are pressured in a continuation of the pullback from the 153.00 level, with demand subdued by the constructive risk tone and ahead of the 2yr JGB auction later.
